I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will promote and increase the 
participation of private capital in climate financing in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The 
TA will address the information and resource asymmetry in climate change mitigation investment 
to  improve  access to  finance,  the  carbon market,  and  technological  tools  among financial 
investors,  technology  providers,  and  policy  makers.  This  will  support  evidence-based  and 
strategically  sound  investment  that  would  generate  sustainable  greenhouse  gas  emissions 
reduction impacts. 
 
2.  The TA is not included in the current country operations business plan1  for PRC, but it is 
in line with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030 operational priority on tackling 
climate change, building climate resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability.2 The TA 
was prepared in consultation with the government and is based on the latest government priorities 
in the area of climate change.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  As part of its Paris Agreement commitment, the Government of the PRC pledged to peak 
its carbon dioxide (CO ) emissions in around 2030, strive to peak earlier, and increase the 
2
nonfossil fuel share of its primary energy consumption to about 20% by 2030.4 The TA supports 
the Ministry of Ecology and Environment (MEE) of the PRC in using carbon as a financial 
derivative to advance climate financing to promote the early peaking of CO  emissions. The MEE 
2
has begun preparatory work, such as identifying nationally determined contributions (NDCs) 
projects in the PRC, undertaking nationwide carbon trading, and establishing climate bond 
standards. 
 
4.  To finance the country’s transition to a low-carbon model, it is essential to (i) increase the 
development and utilization of nonfossil fuels as the primary energy sources, (ii) enhance energy 
conservation and emissions reduction, and (iii) improve energy efficiency. However, various 
constraints have resulted in a two-thirds decline in clean energy project investments during 2017–
2019. For instance, while clean energy development projects increased during 2014–2018, the 
utilization and integration of clean energy remains a formidable challenge. Moreover, because of 
reduced subsidies for renewable energy development and the large front-end investments in 
research  and  development  for  advanced  low-carbon  technology  and associated  long  cost-
recovery cycle, financing for advanced technologies is limited. Major reforms are therefore 
needed. 
 
5.  The global economic downturn and the impact of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic hampers the PRC’s efforts to transition to low-carbon development. The market effects 
of green bonds5 issued by the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) was similar to any other bond and 
had little impact on low-carbon financing and investment. Progress is hindered by (i) the limited 
assets and lack of collateral in technologically advanced companies; (ii) the absence of a sector-

model can be converted into an investment logic to deliver the strategic fit to potential investors; 
(iii) challenges in the traceability and accuracy of CO  emissions reduction, particularly for green 
2
investors to whom climate financing additionality needs to be proved;6 (iv) financial institutions’ 
frequent lack of specialized low-carbon subsector knowledge and difficulty analyzing the growth 
potential,  climate  finance  additionality,  and  future  cash  flow  generated  by  climate  change 
mitigation technologies; and (v) the more limited availability of and accessibility to financial 
resources and tools to enable monitoring, reporting, and verification, which has hampered 
innovation and market penetration of climate change mitigation technologies in key industry 
sectors. 
 
6.  There is therefore an urgent need to create a climate change financing acceleration 
platform and deploy fintech to (i) define climate change financing and climate change mitigation 
technologies, (ii) break the deadlock between technology provider and financier to reach a 
mutually recognizable tracing and verification system through blockchain applications, and (iii) 
drive investment to the low-carbon technology innovation areas that are needed most. To achieve 
this, the TA identifies carbon and its integration with blockchain as an innovative financial 
derivative requiring a government-led climate change financing acceleration platform to leverage 
private investments and further develop carbon trading. Further, the proposed platform provides 
a market-oriented and fintech-driven system to consolidate climate change mitigation projects 
through climate financing policies and standards, gearing toward quantifiable and tradable CO  
2
emissions reduction,  consistent  with  the  government’s  task  of  promoting  climate financing. 
Moreover, the platform intends to identify cutting-edge climate financing projects available for 
ADB’s future support and investment.  
 
7.  The TA will build on ADB’s past support for climate change and clean investment in the 
PRC. This include the improvement of the design of the national carbon emissions trading system, 
pilot  testing  of  the  Tianjin  and  Shanghai  emissions  trading  schemes,  renewable  energy 
development,  energy  efficiency,  low-carbon  infrastructure,  and  carbon capture  and  storage 
projects enhancing energy conservation and greenhouse gas emissions reduction. The TA will 
also support efforts to mainstream climate finance through the introduction of climate finance 
targets  in  development  and  commercial  banks  in  alignment  with  ADB  past  policy 
recommendations.7   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: carbon emission peaking point in the PRC 
achieved earlier than 2030.8 The TA will have the following outcome: investment-efficient policies 
and guidelines for climate financing and climate-resilient technologies improved.9 
 
 
6  Climate financing additionality means a climate-friendly project that is not financially viable unless climate finance 
support is in place. 
7  2019. ADB. Climate Change and Air Pollution: Issues and Recommendations for the 14th Five-Year Plan. ADB’s 
Support for the People’s Republic of China’s 14th Five-Year Plan (unpublished). Manila. 
8  Government of the People’s Republic of China. 2015. The Nationally Determined Contribution to Climate Change. 
Beijing. 
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Climate financing scope, standards and evaluation methodology, policies 
and implementation guidelines for climate change mitigation projects formulated. To 
address the existing investment obstacles, the TA will define, formulate, and promulgate climate 
financing  standards  under  the  supervision  of  a  climate  financing  steering  committee.  In 
accordance with these standards, the TA will develop methodologies to evaluate climate change 
mitigation technologies for the development of low-carbon projects.10 The TA will design an 
evaluation methodology and guidelines focusing on (i) technology soundness, (ii) project design 
and development, (iii) financial due diligence, (iv) emissions reduction and climate resilience 
effectiveness, and (v) climate financing additionality. The TA will establish a climate financing 
mitigation acceleration project database based on the climate financing standards, evaluation 
methodology, and guidelines, in line with the government’s climate change NDC categorization. 
The climate financing standards and guidelines will serve as the basis for developing climate 
change mitigation technology projects and will be used by financial institutions and potential 
investors. 
 
10.  Output 2: Fintech climate change financing acceleration platform established. The 
TA  will  develop  a  blockchain-applied  system  for  “Chinese  Certified  Emissions  Reductions 
(CCERs) Plus” to enhance the functionality of the PRC’s Emissions Trading System to be 
deployed by the China Beijing Environment Exchange.11 The TA will digitalize the operation and 
management of the climate financing  project database (para. 8), which will cover the climate 
change mitigation technology impact analysis, technology maturity categorization, the upgrading 
of CCERs to CCERs Plus, carbon asset management, and emissions allowance through a 
blockchain-based accreditation and trading system. This would enhance the benefits of financing 
climate change mitigation projects with proven future value by enabling monitoring, reporting, and 
verification of their CO emissions reductions. The TA will establish an operational link between 
2 
the platform and the established government-led climate change NDC database, the trading of 
CCERs Plus, and the sector-led emissions allowance. Through the advanced application of the 
blockchain system, the platform will also demonstrate scenarios for developing a carbon token 
equivalent for climate change mitigation projects as part of its function to incentivize wider public 
and private participation in traceable and verifiable climate-friendly investments 
 
11.  Output 3: Capacity building and knowledge sharing on climate financing enhanced. 
The  TA  will  draft  and publish  the  guidelines on  climate financing  projects  investment  and 
evaluation and will disseminate the know-how and improve access to such information through 
surveys, interviews, conferences, and the media. The TA will organize training courses and 
workshops for government units, financial institutions, industry associations, energy service 
companies, and climate change mitigation technology holders on the application of the climate 
financing  standards  and  practical  use  of  the climate  change  acceleration  platform  through 
blockchain technology; and obtain feedback on lessons and experiences for regular upgrading of 
the methodologies. The TA will promote the guidelines internationally to encourage collaboration 
and knowledge sharing on climate financing among ADB developing members to reinforce 
regional and global efforts to tackle climate change. 
 
 
10 The Climate Financing Steering Committee was established in October 2019 and draws its membership from the 
MEE, the PBOC, the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission, the National Development and Reform 
Commission, and the Ministry of Finance. 
11 CCERs are the certified emissions reduction in the carbon market in accordance with the government’s voluntary 
emissions reduction management methods. The upgraded version of CCERs to incentivize wider CO2 reduction 
through blockchain-enabled technology could be named “CCERs Plus.”

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.27 million, of which $1.00 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Clean Energy Fund12 under the Clean Energy Financing Partnership Facility, and 
administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. As the development 
and promotion of climate financing is one of the key priorities of the Climate Change Department 
of the MEE, the government will also have domestic funding to support the formulation of its 
climate change NDC database and the associated trading platforms, as well as provincial-level 
climate financing infrastructure, totaling about CNY50 million.  
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, office supplies, information and documents relevant to the implementation of the 
TA, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The TA will be implemented over 25 months, from September 2020 to October 2022. ADB 
will administer the TA. ADB’s PRC Resident Mission will select, supervise, and evaluate the 
consultants. The Climate Change Department of the MEE will be the executing agency.

17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to the Government of the People’s Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Climate financing scope, standards and evaluation methodology, policies and implementation 
guidelines for climate change mitigation projects formulated 
1.1 Conduct study and research on the barriers for financial institutions and investors to finance or invest in 
climate change mitigation technologies and projects (September 2020–November 2020). 
1.2 Define, formulate, and promulgate the climate financing standards (September 2020–December 2020). 
1.3 Formulate climate financing and technology evaluation methodology and guidelines (January 2021–April 
2021). 
1.4 Establish climate financing mitigation acceleration project database based on the climate financing 
standards (December 2020–May 2022). 
2.  Fintech climate change financing acceleration platform established 
2.1 Establish platform framework (March 2021–July 2021). 
2.2 Develop the blockchain infrastructure for upgrading of the CCERs Plus, carbon asset management, and 
emissions allowance (August 2021–December 2021). 
2.3 Demonstrate carbon token equivalent and its application scenarios anchored in the climate change 
mitigation acceleration project database from the climate change financing acceleration platform (January 
2022–September 2022). 
2.4 Develop operational links among the climate change financing acceleration platform, carbon trading, and 
the NDC project database (July 2022–October 2022). 
3.  Capacity building and knowledge sharing on climate financing enhanced 
3.1 Consolidate handbooks or training materials on climate financing guidelines (January 2022–April 2022). 
3.2 Organize workshops and training on climate financing technology evaluation methodology and the use of 
the climate change financing acceleration platform (May 2022–August 2022). 
3.3 Organize international experience-sharing roundtables and workshops (August 2022–October 2022).
